<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

Regarding your second question, converting a .bmp image to a .jpeg2000 image can be done using the Java Advanced Imaging (JAI) library. Here's a simple example:

<<<api>>>: com.sun.media.imageio.plugins.J2KImageWriter
<<<code>>>: J2KImageWriter jw = new J2KImageWriter();
jw.setImageWriterProperties(new ImageWriterProperties(new File("output.j2k")));
jw.write(new BufferedImage(1, 1, BufferedImage.TYPE_INT_RGB), "input.bmp");

This example reads an input .bmp image and writes it to an output .j2k file using the J2KImageWriter class. The output file is specified using the ImageWriterProperties class. The input image is assumed to be a 1x1 pixel image of type BufferedImage.TYPE\_INT\_RGB. You may need to adjust the code based on your specific use case.
